As per The 7 Essential Meta-Questions of Every Beta:

What’s the “elevator pitch” for our site?

Imagine you’ve just gotten on an elevator with a friendly stranger. You have precisely one floor to describe your community to them. What would you say? The elevator pitch is a brief sentence that describes what your site is about. Every word counts!

Once decided, it can be sliced and diced to form:

  • the tagline
  • the motto
  • the blurb under the logo
  • a set of reserved domain names
  • a convenience redirect “nickname” for the site
  • perhaps eventually the domain name in some form

(Due to a variety of practical difficulties with domain names, we prefer to de-emphasize domain name selection. Most sites will retain their topic.stackexchange.com names indefinitely.)

Naming is hard — really hard. But if you can come up with a sensible elevator pitch for your community, it’s a great starting point.

For more detail see: Stack Exchange Naming for Dummies

From The 7 Essential Meta Questions of Every Beta:

  1. What should our FAQ contain?

Much of the FAQ will be somewhat boilerplate: “be nice,” “how to create an account,” “how to ask questions” — it’s all pretty static. Even the sections about “what kind of questions should I (not) ask here?” comes primarily from the Definition phase of Area 51.

But the questions you want to discuss in meta are those issues specific to your site that need to be mentioned in the FAQ.

Take the Super User FAQ as an example:

Super User is for computer enthusiasts and power users.
If you have a question about …

    * computer hardware
    * computer software

and it is not about …

    * videogames or consoles
    * websites or web services like Facebook, Twitter, and WordPress
    * electronic devices, media players, cell phones or smart phones,

except insofar as they interface with your computer * a shopping or buying recommendation

It took us almost a year to figure out the list of “we want these sort of questions” and “we don’t want these sort of questions” on Super User. Area 51 gave you a head start but you should also be working out other FAQ-related issues specific to your topic and your community.

This is not an answer to that question but a clarification of the word "beliefs"; its usage in this sense is ambiguous as it can be construed to refer to any number of variously held beliefs. (I.E. "Beliefs" is ambiguous as it can refer to facts or faith and no one responding to the question would know which to correctly respond to.)

Many questions use terms whose ambiguities make definitive answers nearly impossible as they lack specificity. On the one hand, it might be said these are badly worded questions as they are posed. On the other, likelier hand, the questions aren't badly worded, they are standard semantic problems with Atheist as a label.

How should we deal with questions that are loaded, or burdened by, semantic issues?
Title: Are Questions loaded by semantics, boundaries, & definitions?

Body:
They should be clearly labeled as semantic. That is, when a question has ambiguous language, or is otherwise muddling in the definition of a term, it should clearly labeled as a debate over semantics. The question linked above is unable to be authoritatively answered and can only seek to discover the semantic boundaries. These semantic discussions are problematic because they are excessively discussion-y and only lend themselves to community wikis.

However, they are not off-topic or bad-subjective as they can be answered well. It is up to the community to have good standards and to maintain the site and to keep it from being an echo chamber. In the case of semantic questions, we can have exhaustive, collaborative answers that objectively elucidate the semantic boundaries and ambiguities of a question, or "problem".

There are many questions, in real life and on this site, involving defining what an Atheist is. We don't need to make more problems by ignoring the fact that most of the language is borrowed from, and interpreted in the context of, Religion.
I think, in most of these issues, the question is obviously unclear and should be voted to be closed.

We can create an actual resource here for understanding atheism, and I apologize if this seems like I am taking an alternate route to use a soap box, but many of the questions are crating an atmosphere of a Flame-war.

Sadly though, it's an intellectually dishonest one since this is more of an echo chamber currently.

Looking at the questions so far, I see this confirmed:

Most, if not all questions generate a discussion instead of the clear, straightforward question-answer format that Stack Exchange promotes1. Now, that’s not a bad thing – in fact, I believe that the topic is inherently debatable (even if we all agree on some tenets of atheism).

But I don’t see how that fits with the question-answer methodology provided by this platform. The general FAQ of Stack Exchange discourages discussions, and the technical implementation of the platform all but forbids it.

We should keep an eye on that and see how it can be mitigated. I would be very interested in a discussion platform on atheism. But Stack Exchange clearly isn’t the place for it. I also think that an atheism-related FAQ (discussing definitions, theological arguments and fallacies) could still be very useful, and this is where the Stack Exchange platform may shine.

So even though none of the questions are really off-topic, we should perhaps concede that discussions should be discouraged more actively.

Title: Is there a danger that we might run out of new questions?

Body:
We should go with something clear and descriptive. Start with a brief definition of bare atheism, describe strong and weak atheists, what gnostic and agnostic means, and to finish up mention monism and dualism, that is, monists are woo-free and dualists are all new agey (can you tell I'm a monist?) I'm going to ignore formatting mostly for now, and my writing style is bare. This is also community wiki, edits have revision histories, so go nuts guys!

Atheism is, simply, the lack of belief in a deity or deities. No more, no less. There are different philosophies within atheist communities that deal with the finer points of disbelief.

The terms gnostic and agnostic refer to whether one believes they can know the answer. In the context of atheism, a gnostic atheist believes there is provably no god or gods. An agnostic atheist is the opposite, they believe one cannot truly know whether a god or gods exist. These two terms are often considered synonymous with strong and weak atheism, respectively. [I'm not sure this last bit is completely accurate. I'm a strong atheist, but consider myself an agnostic. I will say God doesn't exist, but I don't claim I can know for sure. Any ideas?]

[Someone that's better with monist/dualist philosophy want to do that, or should we leave it out? I think it adds some benefits to mention that many of us are monist, and leave the supernatural completely out of the equation.]

I think we should stick to forums like reddit and AtheistNexus until we have the moderators to handle the Christian trolls it will bring in. It also means we'll be more fully developed when the influx occurs.

I sort of agree with Josiah. But I think that Nomæd's proposal is great. I am all for inviting atheism promoters and celebrities. I think we need that kind of bonding, lacking other common grounds that religious people often have.

There is a huge list of serious, not-so-serious, and outright jocular arguments for God's existence. Well, not the best example of a list (too much mockery), but it gave me the idea. On a related note, could someone suggest a better list?

What if someone goes through the list, selecting the most serious and seemingly persuasive arguments, and posts requests to concisely refute them as separate questions tagged with the "debate-points" tag? Would that be considered spamming? Or is it a legit way to fill this Q&A service with useful Q&A's?

I can think of at least one reason in favour of doing that: it might help to have a database of refutations when the inevitable influx of Christians occurs. And at least one reason against doing that: it might be considered “cheating” when the healthiness of the beta is evaluated.

Title: Too chatty? Too personal? Does Q&A work for us?

Body:
I Concur. I think the important thing to accept here is this: IF this format is to work, it requires active community participation.

In this case, it means commenting NEGATIVELY about bad questions, editing questions, closing off-topic posts, etc. If WE police the site (possibly angering a few recipients of our school-marmish corrections), then the content will slowly whittle down to the list of good/legitimate questions that work on a Q&A site.

I don't think the current state of affairs is ONLY because Q&A is a tough fit for this philosophical topic, but because the community hasn't stepped up to rein in and define the purpose and scope of the site.

Some of the tools to do so are not available to us in this beta stage. For example, the right to edit other people's posts. It will get better. That said, I read that a "healthy" site coming out of beta has 1500 questions. We're at 145, and the questions aren't that great (agreeing with your assessment of all the list questions and broad subjective questions).

Time will tell, but I think it CAN work, with a bit more active/aggressive community involvement in editing, down-voting, voting to close, merging good answers together, etc.

It seems that a lot of questions posted on this site ask for generalizations about atheism or atheists. They usually take the form, "Do atheists all agree about [X]?"

These questions usually get at least one answer along these lines, "Atheists only have one thing in common: lack of belief in God's. Nothing else." The answer seems to be saying, "Stop wasting our time" and (at least in SOME cases) is dismissive of a really interesting question, or an analysis considering the possibility that the group of people making up the population of "atheists" might have some commonality worth investigating.

In short, this answer is as much a conversation stopper as "God did it" coming from believers who don't want to do scientific explanation to understand deeper causal connections in natural observations.

Can we all agree that, "Yes, it is a given that the only absolutely common thing about atheists is "lack of belief in deities," and then stop wasting time posting that response to dozens of questions stifling/chilling more meaningful or interesting discussion?
Title: Does Atheism REALLY mean "one thing and one thing only"? Can we purge/discourage this from the site? Should we?

Body:
Using Shift+Enter lets you put line breaks in your comment as you type. They'll disappear in your comment, but if you like "formatting" as you type, go for it.

I agree and see where you are coming from but I think that people visiting the site will have all sorts of questions and will benefit from multiple view points on the same topic, one will stick in the mind of one person and another will ring true to someone else. They wont get such a simple idea. Its the repetition that will change the minds of others. This site wont last if it is paired down too much. I think voting down the worst offenders is best. I think part of what your seeing in the moderation of the questions is trying avoid a platform of ambiguous discussions. Let's say, this is not really the place to discuss things so much as it is the place where you come to give an answer to a question once the discussions are done. So what is happening is a the beginnings of the development of the structure, and the exertion of control to stay within it's intended format.

I think one challenge to this is the subjective nature of the topic. A lot of the stack exchange sites are technical sites like computer programing, where there are definitive answers for things. This topic because of it's inherent simplicity, and the huge range of topics it effects is harder to pigeon hole into just a Q&A format. The answers to many questions are a persons personal convictions and not always easy to voice in definitive terms. I also think that there is an avoidance to stating a definitive answer that appears to speak for the whole group. I think that we respect each others convictions enough to realize many different points of view exist so we would rather discuss it instead of infer we have the correct answer. So were working on trying to find out how to best make it all fit.

I see your point about picking the best answer in some of those questions. Two of the questions are mine and I wondered about that myself. I tried to ask those questions not in the spirit of coming up with a best answer but, in an attempt to provide information about the atheist experience to those who don't know. I tried to formulate the question to fit within the Q&A format to elicit straight forward answers that are not particularly designed to open up discussion.

It seems to that without the type of questions above we would only be getting questions on where to find debates on the net? and Where can I buy an beanie advocating atheism or secularism?.

So do we want a site that answers questions about the atheist experience or where to buy beanies?

If the above questions are not within what you perceive as the right ones, give some examples of which ones are correct.

IMHO, "Do atheists all agree about [X]?" is perhaps a badly formulated question, but the idea is good once it's asked as "As an atheist/non-believer, do you agree than/on [X], and how do you explain this position without the super-natural?", when it's relevant.

I think the question

How does being an atheist influence your feelings about death?

is OK for a Q&A site. Maybe it should be rephrased as

Are atheists afraid of death?

or

If this life is all there is, why do atheists bother?

The last one being close to a duplicate of the question about the meaning of life.

Anyway, what I mean is that this is the kind of question that someone who is curious about atheism might ask. So it definitely deserves an answer, even if there is probably not a single objective answer in this case, except maybe for refuting preconceptions non-atheists have about these questions. (Like "atheism=nihilism" or something like that.)

But on the whole, I share your feeling that the Q&A format seems to be working much less well than I had hoped.

In another thread, I've tried to isolate the characteristics of questions that fit into the format:

1/ The ones that obviously allow for an objective answer. Ex: Is there a relation between atheism and intelligence?

2/ The ones that ask for help about dealing with a situation. Ex: I don't know how to deal with [the argument from Design]

3/ The ones that ask for clarification because of some misconception about atheism. Ex: Why do atheists bother if this is the only life we have?

4/ The ones that are of the list type. Ex: What books should an atheist read?

(I initially bunched 2 and 3 together.)

I've been active in other StackExchange sites (StackOverflow especially) for over a year, and I agree with Rob that the questions that we have so far in this site are not up to what one would expect from a mature Q&A site.

However, atheism itself is a topic that doesn't generate questions as software development or biking may do, in my opinion. When you are a biking nut or a software developer, specific questions pop up into your mind a dozen a day, and a Q&A site like this is a perfect place to find answers. I don't think atheism is like that, because atheism is not a hobby or a trade. It is a position, a stance, a philosophy. And, as such, it generates intricate debates rather than to-the-point questions that can be answered with straightwforward replies.

Unless, of course, we want this to become a site where people come to find beanies. ;-)

In summary, I think that we shouldn't expect this site to be as "pure" Q&A as other StackExchange sites. A certain degree of debate and discussion is going to occur, and that is great. What is more, if it didn't happen, or if it were to be censored because it doesn't fit with the nature of the site, I think many people would be off.

I wonder whether we want or should actively try to attract non-atheist people to the site. Apparently, all of us here are atheist, and that is cool, but I think that having theist people contribute to the forum may have benefits. To start with, they would be exposed to atheism, and they might even convert! :-) Secondly (and seriously), they would have the opportunity to learn and discuss things related to atheism in a relaxed and anonymous environment.

Of course, this may have disadvantages as well. Trolling would be an obvious one.

What do you think? Is this forum for theists as well? If so, how do we get them here?
Title: Is this only for atheists?

Body: I'm inclined to think that since this is a Q&A forum, it should be more for theists than atheists. Who would have more questions about atheism? People who are not atheists or have taken the first steps into the direction of atheism and are still doubting.

I think it has become urgent that we more or less determine what will be an acceptable question and what not. Some guidelines should be at the disposal of moderators and other participants. I think most of us agree that this stack should not deviate into a debate forum, there are enough debate forums for that already. Nevertheless, since atheism is not comparable to physics or programming, some debating will be inevitable, so we shouldn't shut it out completely.

I think, as a first rule, the question should not be a simple debating matter. Debating withtin the thread can be allowed, but the question should in principle admit an objective answer, even if the answer is not known yet, which would be a real research question.

I've tried to isolate some of the characteristics of questions that fit into the Q&A format:

1/ The ones that obviously allow for an objective answer. Ex: Is there a relation between atheism and intelligence? ; Are atheists, statistically speaking as a group, more or less loyal than the rest of the population?

2/ The ones that ask for help about dealing with a situation. Ex: *I don't know how to deal with [the argument from Design]. ; The one question I don't have a good answer for - what happens to our body's energy when we die? *

3/ The ones that ask for clarification because of some misconception about atheism. Ex: Why do atheists bother if this is the only life we have? ; Do placeboes work on atheists?

4/ The ones that are of the list type. Ex: What books should an atheist read? ; Parenting book recommendations

This list is as some suggested incomplete. A way to extend it would be for everyone to review the questions that already have been proposed and see if they fit in one of these 4 categories. If it doesn't, but you still think the question should be considered a valid one, you should propose a new category and some other examples of questions that could fit into it. Then post it here as an answer so that everybody can discuss if we should take up this new category or not.

Title: To death with polling questions! To death with them all.

Body:
The philosophy seems to be a hot one used by people who don't really understand what philosophy is. Philosophy answers questions about:

  1. ontology
  2. conduct/behavior
  3. governance

It does not belong to:

  • every question without an answer
  • any meta-question about religion
  • any normative question

I can understand the confusion. It seems as if the schools of fashion and poshness have fixated with prefixing every sentence not serious enough by itself with "philosophically". Confusing "philosophically", "hypothetically", "pedagogically", "pedantically", and "rhetorically" really is a bad idea.

  • If today was your last day, what would you like to eat?
  • Philosophically, if today was your last day, what would you like to eat? (bad use!)

It is also redundant when used with ethics (which is subset of the philosophy of conduct). I shudder to think of the difficulty differentiating ethics and morality, so let's just hang with the latter... Especially, given the audience of the site now.

For reference, I'll put up the Wikipedia definition of philosophy:

Philosophy is the study of general and fundamental problems, such as those connected with existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language. It is distinguished from other ways of addressing such problems by its critical, generally systematic approach and its reliance on rational argument.

It's not that philosophy would be a good category for this case, but we do seem to lack a tag to accommodate questions about the general landscape of atheistic thinking.

Questions that are specific in their intent on assessing the ethical obligations of an atheist with a specific problem can be accommodated under the ethics-morality (those two, in usage, will need to be synonymous, even though they are different things). In order to pose a question as an ethical dilemma the author must phrase the situation concisely, and outline objectives they seek to have resolved by any acceptable answers.

If the ethical question does not have objectives for the answers to accomplish, then question is too broad in scope, the community should first ask for clarification and vote to close, then down vote if no clarifications are made.

When you think about it, a Q&A site does only make real sense when it is about a topic for which a large number of questions may be posed. These questions need to meet two properties:

  • They need to be non-trivial and in large supply. If we are re-asking the same thing again and again, we are doomed.
  • They need to have known answers (i.e. someone in the community needs to know the answer), and the answer must be clear and more or less objective. If not, we will get into never ending arguments of opinions, and this is not a debate forum.

For example, if the topic were programming, somebody could ask "how do I implement a bubble sort"; there you have a question for which the poor guy does not have an answer, but clear, objective answers do exist, so that's a good question and everybody may have a go at answering it. If the topic were biking, somebody could ask "should I get an alumninium or carbon frame for my 12-year old daughter"; same thing.

But I don't think that atheism is a topic for which large numbers of questions for which clear answers exist can be generated. There are interesting issues to be discussed, sure, and the list that Evan posted at the top of this page is a good example. But real questions with really clear answers? I don't think so.

I have argued somewhere else that the reason why this is so is because atheism is not a field of knowledge. Computer programming or biking are. By "field of knowledge" I mean a discipline with a given ontology, epistemology, theory, method and methodology, where a body of knowledge can be more or less easily identifiable. Atheism is not like this; atheism is a position that one takes, but is not a field of knowledge. That's why it cannot generate large numbers of questions for which clear answers exist.

This leaves us here: either we admit that this kind of very subjective question, which is almost a discussion point rather than a proper question, is fine; or we abandon the idea of having a StackExchange site for atheism.

If anyone wants to prove me wrong, please provide 10 or 20 sample real questions about atheism that we haven't seen before. I can easily generate that number of questions for programming, biking or cooking.

Title: What should be our current etiquette for voting to close and SU editing?

Body:
Our policy around closing needs to reinforce that people aren't answering bad questions.

If a question deserves to be closed, we should vote to close it immediately, comment on the reason, and ask the questionner to edit his question. (Please make one comment explaining why the question needs to be closed; hopefully all voters-to-close will upvote just that comment and it will stick out thus icnreasing the chance people will reread for flaws before answering.) If the questionner does edit the question, we can always reassess and reopen the question.

This is the best policy because:

  • If the question is edited into usefulness, there will be answers that answer a bad question (and might even be upvoted, because people are like that).
  • If the question is edited into usefulness, people who wrote an answer will have wasted their time.
  • If the question is closed in the end, people who wrote an answer will have wasted their time.

Remember, voting to close (and closing, for users with enough rep) are tools to impose that the author edit his or her question. It should be construed as nothing more. Very good questions can be worded poorly, closed, and the author can revise and get their question re-opened. It's like an "Under Construction" sign.

In this scenario mod tools are reserved, the community is working to ask better questions, reasons for editing are explicit, and expectations of questions are reinforced.

As for marking/flagging CW on answerable questions, this is typically reserved for when the question asks for multiple solutions to the same problem, lists of resources for atheism, and the community wants to assemble a variously edited/compiled question/answer to address something specific. That said, we end users are not arbiters of CWifying, it is up to mods to make the determination(links to explanation of CW on cooking.SE).

Remember, a good question (ie one asking for clear-cut objective solutions to a problem) can go through a Rep and voting phase, a bounty phase, and then be converted to CW AFTER without a loss of any Rep. Also there are default rules like where after a question has been edited by 5 different authors it automatically becomes CW (links to What Are CW Posts on m.SO).

Here is a list from cooking.se on when to make edits:

+Reasons to edit:

  • Correct spelling/grammatical errors
  • Clean up formatting
  • Clarify an ambiguous or poorly-phrased question/answer
  • Reverse a downvote (but please use sparingly)

+Do not edit if your intent is to do any of the following:

  • Add your own commentary (use the comments/votes instead)
  • Remove a spam link (use the flags)
  • Significantly alter content or add totally new content (unless Community Wiki)
  • Change British to American spelling, or vice versa
  • Bump the question (unless you also have a legitimate edit to make)
  • Remove a greeting (yes, they're not needed or wanted, but it's rude to edit just for - that reason)

Atheism is a very large subject. While topics such as cooking or programming are clearly defined to one area, atheism touches on many areas of science (both natural and social) as well as philosophy. As such, it makes it trickier to decide whether the question is on-topic or not.

That's why, when we read a question, we need to keep the audience in mind. That is, atheists.

To explain my point, allow me to use an example: Is religion to blame for honor killing?

I posit that this question is off-topic.

When I made that argument in chat, Vitaly rightly pointed out to me that this is a valid anthropological question. That is true. I won't question that. Were we to ask this question an anthropologist of religion, he would answer with an objective answer. However, there lies the problem: this is a site for atheists, not anthropologists.

My point is most visible when you read the answers to the question, two which have at least five upvotes: none of them pass the Back It Up! Principle.

While the question could be answered correctly by an anthropologist, it's not the kind of question that will be answered objectively here nor would an objective answer the most likely to be upvoted here. In other words, the question belongs on Anthropology.SE, not Atheism.SE.

To put it another way, we have to ask ourselves whether the questions is really for "skeptics of an higher power" or whether it's for experts of another discipline, in this case anthropology.

Here is a corollary situation from cooking.se . However, the difference was grounded in a pattern of non-attribution. I think that, for the sake of everyone, we assume first that the user forgot a citation. After a true pattern has emerged we can act as a community to take action.

Additionally, even though @Robert could have added a note that he edited the answer, the answer tells you by whom and how it was edited. Considering he didn't wave a magic diamond wand to erase that, so I think your anger on that fron is likely displaced. I think plagiarism is a major problem for any community that would profess it's expertise, however I hope this isn't just an excuse to bash Robert.

The problem I see is that too many terms are poorly understood, or poorly defined. How many questions do we need on how to define Atheism? That's surely one of the simplest concepts we're going to be dealing with here.

So, with regards to the (terrible) karma discussion, we run into people who disagree on what atheist means, people who disagree on whether buddhists are atheists, people who disagree on what karma means...Yet, there needs to be a simple answer to the question? I don't see how it's possible.

I think the proper course of action should be to remove the user's reputation for that answer and then make it a community wiki answer so that he no longer gets reputation for that answer after adding the source.

Just removing the question would be detrimental, however, because it's really the best answer to that question. While there's another answer that has more upvotes, that answer isn't answering the question. Worse, the third best answer is just a rant.

Evan, you're a top-ranking contributor to this site and someone who seems to have better ideas than most about what should (and should not) be on this site. So, your ideas (and flags) carry a lot of weight. If you asked to have the post deleted, I would have deleted it; It was not compliant. Your flag noted only that it was missing the proper citation. You provided the attribution link right in your flag so I assumed it was preferable to fix the post and make it better than to remove someone's first contribution to this system.

I rolled back the edit. If fixing the post is a problem, I removed my correction. I do not have the technical ability to remove the votes but you, as a community, can decide how to proceed. Here's a quick list of the options, as I see it:

  • Edit the post to make it better and bring it into compliance, or;
  • Leave a comment to the author, giving them a reasonable amount of time to make the corrections.
  • Down-vote the post, if you feel other answers should appear above this answer.
  • Flag the post for moderator attention.

What kind of questions can I ask here?

This site is the place to go when you have questions about atheism and how it fits onto the world stage. It is not only for atheists, but also for anyone else who lives with an atheist, knows an atheist, is scared of atheists, or just wants to understand what is going through the atheistic mind.

We are looking for good questions. This community is all about bringing the experts to the questions and if the questions aren't good enough to draw experts nothing will. Questions need to be focused on a problem or situation that you actually want solved; they are not some pre-tense for a rhetorical moment in the sun for anyone.

If you have a question about:

  • How to carry on an intelligent conversation as or with an atheist
  • How to understand some concept an atheist is talking about
  • The underlying logic behind many timeless arguments and debates
  • Support as or for an atheist who is dealing with cultural displacement

...the hit the Ask Question link and let's fire it up

What about other atheism-related questions? Atheism bumps up against many other disciplines from science to philosophy and has rough edges with theism. That doesn't mean those things are out of bounds, but remember: you're asking about atheism, most likely you're asking an atheist of some stripe, and this isn't a soap box.

Please note that the following subjects are considered off-topic here:

  • Book/Movie/Documentary/Blog swapping ("I need a magic book to prove me right!")
  • General information about religion
  • General information about science
  • General questions pertaining only to philosophy
  • How to humiliate some guy in a coffee shop

That's not to say you can't talk about it in the chat channel, but we are not interested in it here and we cannot tolerate it.

What is Atheism

You may not realize how important a good definition is or how hard it is to come by until a few days talking incessantly about it.

For the purposes of discussion, and this is a debated point up for revision, the community generally uses atheism in a more inclusive sense. That is to say, an atheist is necessarily a person who lacks a belief in [God]. Some of us may favor a stricter definition, like one that eliminates all supernatural explanations and things like that. However, for the sake of having a workable definition that doesn't overly constrict atheism's usefulness as a word generally, it is preferred that we all mean:

An atheist is necessarily a person who lacks a belief in [God]. Atheism is the lack of a belief in [God].

You can use the semantics tag to try to discuss the matter further in questions, but for the overall site, this is the common usage.

Closing, re-opening, editing

In order to engage the community we should (vote to close if bad enough ), ask the questionner to make revisions (to subjective language), make some minor edits to steer them in the correct direction (comment about how edits can be rolled back if it looks like the user is new), and if the question remains unanswerable downvote and vote to close.

Remember, voting to close and closing (for users with enough rep) are tools to impose that the author edit his or her question. It should be construed as nothing more. Very good questions can be worded poorly, closed, and the author can revise and get their question re-opened.

Take pride in your question. Take ownership of it. If you have 5 people who vote to close it, that likely means there are five people who may not have understood what you meant. Clarify yourself in the text of the question. Closed question? It's like an "Under Construction" sign.

In this scenario mod tools are reserved, the community is working to ask better questions, reasons for editing are explicit, and expectations of questions are reinforced. Once you edit, rework, or otherwise improve your question put up a post on meta or in chat to ask for it to be re-opened.

As for marking/flagging CW on answerable questions, this is typically reserved for when the question asks for multiple solutions to the same problem, lists of resources for atheism, and the community wants to assemble a variously edited/compiled question/answer to address something specific. That said, we end users are not arbiters of wikifying, it is up to mods to make the determination(links to explanation of CW on cooking.SE).

The whole "Define Atheism" thing seems to be flopping all over the place. I'm in the "strict dictionary definition" group, and while I think that this definition is in every way sufficient, clearly other people do not agree.

So, instead of another thread asking for a complete definition that everyone will hate, I want to go at it in reverse. The dictionary definition is obviously a good starting point, but people seem to think it's missing something, THEREFORE:

What do you think the "Strict Dictionary Definition" of Atheism LACKS

Short, simple, and to the point please. Try not to put more than one idea per answer, so people can up/down vote each one, and we can (hopefully) come to some kind of consensus.
Title: What *isnt* Atheism.

Body:
It lacks a clear definition of what this "god" thing that atheists don't believe in is. Given the variation in the definition of god among theists and atheists (some consider as the default the Abrahamic god the definition of god), depending on the definition that people endorse, the same person may be an atheist or a theist, that seems problematic.

To explain consider this: Were I think there is an invisible omniscient entity that watches over everyone's life, doesn't interfere in the world, and then acts upon people's deaths to judge our lives based on an arbitrary rubric he/she/it never communicated to the world, and accordingly punish or reward those people. This god has the same observable properties while you are alive as the deist version, so those that aren't committed to metaphysical naturalism and don't rule out the possibility of a deist style god would have to allow the possibility of such a god, making the would be believer a theist. Others might claim that precisely because there is no active intervention, this is more of a ghost, and not really a god.

I added this as a separate answer as you suggested.

I actually think your title makes for a better response to this question than your full OP.

It might be helpful to go through the FAQ and define what atheism isn't rather than giving a positive definition, since we're unlikely to arrive at a positive definition that pleases everybody, and this question about the positive definition of a god like thing or what atheism is, is not a philosophically trivial problem.

So maybe we should list things like:
Atheism is not having no religion: there are religions that have no god (some versions of Buddhism) and there are individuals with no religion that believe in god.
Atheism is not skepticism: one need not be a skeptic about the existence of everything including, e.g., fairies or unicorns to be an atheist.
Atheism is not metaphysical naturalism: metaphysical naturalism is the belief that there are only natural things in the world, i.e. things that can be studied through science.
Atheism is not amoralism: atheists can have strong ethical beliefs that stem from things other than divine/religious writings.
Atheism is not agnosticism: one can believe something without knowing it, and one can know something without believing it. These are separate issues and there can be both Agnostic and Gnostic Atheists.

Please check in on the "What is atheism " heading at What should our FAQ contain? for a draft of one direction. My purpose is to maintain a minimalist definition for the sake of maximum utility across the entire site and to make the definition as encompassing as possible to invite as many contributors as possible. If we have a definition that is too exclusive it will frustrate any contributions.

Atheism exchange is incredibly inconsistent in what gets closed and what gets a ton of upvotes.

If you don't believe in a God and an ultimate meaning, why get up in the morning? - sounds just as much a matter of personal opinion (as opposed to having a definite answer) as How does being an atheist influence your feelings about death?

And yet one is closed, and the other has zero close votes.

What's the deal with this? Am I mistaken in my judgement that the former question has no definitive answer and is unsuitable? Or should it have been closed?

Another example, this time involving a question of mine:

  • Poll, zero close, 17 upvotes: Is it tough being an atheist in your country?
  • Poll, closed, 2 upvotes: Favorite atheism and rational thinking entertainer

In this case, I feel the latter is at least somewhat suitable, in that it lends itself to a popularity vote. The former can have conflicting answers about the same country.

If we don't want such questions then I think we're doing a poor job of closing them. But I also think that if we do that then there will be almost nothing left on this site. Hence I propose to leave questions like "how do you feel about death", "is it tough being an atheist" and "favourite atheism entertainer" open.

To further highlight my point about inconsistency, here are some responses I have received, indirectly, in chat:

  • "I'm not touching the country thread because it's actually interesting to read" - this is exactly what I mean! Where's the consistency? Vote close if you don't like? But what if you had come and closed it before it became interesting?...
  • "if the community embraces [the poll], it elevates beyond a poll and becomes a resource of sorts. in this case of anecdotes" - but whether the community "embraces" it (upvotes enough) depends on how long it took to close it, which is a completely random variable (depends on how many "close all polls" adherents are online)
Title: Is "Atheism" community extremely inconsistent in judging what to close?

Body:
I'm having trouble getting answers that apply to my question. Does anybody have any feedback?

The media enjoys the revenues of a good shock story about a shocking work of art involving theism or atheism. As with any other polarizing conversation, the two are not served by fanning the vitriol. Atheists and theists are better served by art works that can motivate them to a better understanding of the others' perspective and keeps them from talking past each other.

What kind of a dialog, or it's phrasing, successfully engages both atheists and theists in works of art? Are there specific themes, or perhaps ways of pulling together a work that will make it one that challenges atheists and theists in such a way that there is communication between the two? How do successful art works differ from the works that break off conversation and cauterize both camps?

An interesting example of an attempt at dialog between the two camps was when the displays of Damien Hirst (atheist painter/sculpter) and Bill Viola (works about martyrs and saints) were put up in St. Paul's Cathedral. It was a dialog opportunity for everyone willing to be silent for a few minutes while they absorbed the work. Many of the religions and other social groups solidify and expand their influence by engaging in cross-belief dialog; what do successful works have that challenge both groups to understand the other, rather than simply repulse ?

some comments: - I seek agreeable areas of art (the shared language) that can engage atheists and theists alike, and challenge them to understand the other, rather than simply repulse. For instance, the entire history of medieval art is based in devotional works that are compelling to even the most secular of observers. High-relief carvings in naves of demons were meant as proselytizing mechanisms for illiterate peasants. This is a tactic that today is interesting and food for discussion to both camps for its over-the-top nature. Fecal Jesus, however, repulses dialog

Title: Is there a way to delete my account completely?

Body:

Note, that when you post, you are posting here with the cc-by-sa license, which allows other to share your created content provided that they attribute it to you, the author.

Body:
I see Atheism.SE as no different than, say, a Graphic Design SE would be. We are here to talk about advancing our understanding of each other, to advance the 'state of the art' of our practice (if you can call atheism a practice) and we tend to react to outsiders like a Graphic Design SE would react if you came in with a question like:

"Is Graphic Design really necessary? Isn't content King?"

It isn't the point of that SE.

Atheism.SE isn't about debating the validity of atheism. And while much if it could end up being an echo chamber, I have actually been very impressed with the level of discourse here. And a general acceptance to use the questions of theists that join the site as a way to categorize defenses for their arguments. Few questions have been closed for being off topic if they offered an interesting argument to debunk.

Only out-and-out insults have been closed, as far as I have seen.

There is (and always has been) an "Us against them" mentality in the Atheist mainstream, but in more recent times we've been getting aggressive "evangelical" atheists, and that's substantially colored the debate.

In my personal opinion, this sort of a belief is your personal business. If a bunch of theists are trying to get some annoying religious law passed, I'll oppose that. And I don't particularly enjoy their stupid billboards (well, some of them make me ell oh ell, but other than that, I don't enjoy them). But I honestly don't care what other people believe.

Unfortunately, on both sides of the debate, there are people who very much care. People who have a definite opinion on the existence of god, who think that everyone who doesn't agree with their belief is bad/stupid. And, as in all cases where people don't agree, they fight it out.

Just human nature.

This is the best policy because:

  1. If the question is edited into usefulness, there will be answers that answer a bad question (and might even be upvoted, because people are like that).
  2. If the question is edited into usefulness, people who wrote an answer will have wasted their time.

Title: Too Local is a bad reason to close, specify in question title and let it stand!

Body:
I think that this kind of question is perfectly OK as long as the fact that it is localised is made explicit.

On the contrary, questions that assume a particular location (often the US) without making it explicit are a problem.

So, if you do as you say and make it explicit in the question (body or, preferably, title), I will have no problem at all. I have argued along these lines here.
I wonder if people asked most of their pre-existing questions during the first few days of beta, with only a trickle of new questions coming now.

Books are a great resource and reference for atheists. Atheists also have many interests and reasons for looking for resources. Just as Christianity books have many, many sub-categories, so can atheism.

However, in trying to keep in line with the suggestions over at the stackexchange blog, we are looking for a solution on managing our book questions:

It is OK to edit a question to make it more general. With the power of editing comes the power to take someone’s selfish, very specific question, and edit it a little bit until they’re asking the more general question that hundreds of people encounter. For example, if someone asks, “I set up a web server at home but I can’t access it from work,” it’s OK to rewrite the question as, “What things should I check when a web server running at home is not visible on the Internet?” In fact, sometimes selfish, stupid questions of the “do my homework” variety can be easily edited into a form where the answer will provide an extremely valuable resource for the internet at large.

Don’t answer questions that have already been answered elsewhere. Yeah, you might earn a couple of points of reputation, but, because you are duplicating content, you are actually making the internet worse. Why? Because that answer might be true today, but as technology changes, it might not be true tomorrow. There are almost certainly thousands of wrong facts on Stack Overflow already, which may have been true when they were written but are no longer true. These facts will pollute the Internet for years. This problem is not tractable if we allow Stack Overflow to become just an endless river of questions and answers. It has to be more like a Wikipedia of Questions and Answers, with canonical answers that can be edited in one place, if we are ever going to stand a chance of keeping all the information that we expose to the Internet at least reasonably correct.

Of special note is the concluding paragraph:

Help us build a great library of canonical answers. If you keep seeing the same form of questions, whether it’s mod_rewrite rules on Server Fault, freezing computers on Super User, or how to use regular expressions to parse HTML, write a great, canonical answer, once and for all. Make it community wiki so that as many other people as possible can make it great. Work really hard on writing something that is clear, concise, and understandable by as wide an audience as possible.

Please list below your ideas for solutions on keeping the book suggestions from becoming too specific, repetitive, and toxic to the internet. Please note, in the majority of cases, any request for a list should be community wiki since it is basically unanswerable and completely open-ended.

Title: How should we manage books on atheism as questions?

Body:
We should have one massive book thread, each sub-category should be in the form of an answer:

Q: What books are recommended for atheists?

A: Here are some recommendations for atheists about parenting... (followed by CW list)

A: Here are some recommendations for atheists on skepticism... (followed by CW list)

  • Pro: When we have one question, any future questions about books can be marked exact-duplicate, and the questionner can be forwarded to the book thread
  • Pro: Simpler updating of any information or new books means the lists should remain up to date. Having a single question means that the list will be more manageable.
  • Con: When we have one question on books, individual books/answers cannot be voted up as 'best'
  • Issues: devising a method for making some books more recommended based on the community

We should have neatly categorized sub-questions for atheism book recommendations that are general enough to be interesting and narrow enough to give a good array of books. This is currently how the questions marked [books] work:

  • Pro: When we have multiple questions on books, individual books/answers can be voted up as 'best'
  • Con: When we have multiple questions, it is difficult to try to say this question should be closed when there's another one just like it in most respects out there with a bunch of answers
  • Pro/Con: Q/A's remaining up to date will rely on the people interested in that particular list of answers. (May not be as much of an issue since a book on atheism isn't likely to be outdated as quickly as a book on programming)
  • Issues: We may end up with an unmanageable number of lists since each of these questions will be in the form of [atheism-books] + {[empiricism],[naturalism],[anti-empiricism],[anti-naturalism],[woo],[anti-woo], ...} and can extend as far as there are niches in atheism.

Given that today books are only one type of resource or educating one's self, I think that it would be useful to have a Community Wiki for atheism resources. This should include books, websites, movies, podcasts, comics, tv series, etc.

Note that this answer is a superset of mfg's, and shares the pros and cons of it, though it adds:

  • Pro: This will also roll up other resources such as films and websites as well.
  • Con: This could potentially be a monster of a thread.

Title: Have we been too restrictive in what we allow and close?

Body:
I think this is one of the more important areas and definitely not out of scope. There are many questions we've been asked over the years, and it would be excellent to have a FAQ category that addresses these issues. For example, I was once given a fundamentalist pamphlet on why radiocarbon dating was wrong. With an education as a scientist, it was easy enough to refute, but someone not armed with that knowledge could easily be flummoxed by the arguments. Collecting a set of prepackaged answers to this kind of misleading information would be A Good Thing, and it can be presented in an objective way, devoid of personal opinions.

On the other hand, it's also legit to ask about subjective issues. Someone who doesn't understand can be educated by explaining the breadth of personal answers to such a question. Since education is one of the more powerful ways we can influence a misguided belief in the invisible, it's equally important to harvest such questions, although they should be gathered in a different category to the more objective questions.

For a Question & Answer site, my gut reaction is that we are spending too much time quibbling about the answers in the comments section.

Instead we should not be posting those (what I consider to be) burdensome commentary digressions; rather we should be taking that creative energy and asking separate questions that can actually engage more users than the answerer (and his/her compatriots) and the commenter. This way it isn't some rebel force versus the hegemony of an answer where the comments can only be upvoted. The merits of the critiques could then be up/down-voted the way this site is supposed to work.

We need to restrict comments on answers to things like: "this is off-topic, wrong, useless, piling on, rhetorical, etc". What we currently have are comments that question the premise of an answer (argument), engage the semantics of the authors usage, or nibble away some petty point - and these instead could have been real questions where the critique could be voted on based on its merits.

StackExchange works with questions that are either objective or that have satisfying subjective answers. If there are too few such questions on atheism, then so be it. It is possible for a topic to be too narrow.

Take a StackExchange site on the politics of Tuvalu as an example. The whole country has population of about 10,000. It's unlikely that such a site will garner enough traction to work, unless Tuvalu has an unusually politicalized population that is very active on the Internet.

I would argue we should be rolled in with religion or philosophy. Currently, a lot of interesting question to atheists fall off-topic but would be on-topic in religion. Alternatively, if we're merged with philosophy then the whole site would have enough volume even if the philosophy of religion questions are only a small fraction of it. Perhaps that, with Philosophy.SE site, more expert level questions would be asked as well.

Obviously, though, there are challenges by having such broad sites. In both religion and philosophy, a lot of people they are experts or knowledgeable when they are clearly not. It might be problematic to get the right answers upvoted, because of tribalism, dogma, and partisanship.

I believe that we should be allowing marginally subjective questions that we can answer with some meaningful-to-athiests responses. An example might be: "Should Atheists be Educated about Religion?" Which I asked a while ago and it was closed.

There are meaningful insights into Atheism here. Mainly in the justification of the Yes/No answer. Arguments for why it is helpful. Arguments for why it isn't needed to prove Atheism.

The "Right Answer" would likely address both concerns and discuss the implications of both stances.

I think your question assumes that this topic is somehow easy. For many peole, it is not. Letting go of lifelong beliefs, ones that give a lot of comfort is not easy. There are many people who are frustrated with their particular church or community and this is leading them to consider atheism. I say, give them a break, let them work through their crazy questions. Religion has been around for a long time and has a lot power over people, expecting anyone to just dump it quickly based on a logical fallacy or two is unreasonable.

I know that there are already a shocking number of closed questions, so maybe this is not a good time to be suggesting being more stringent. But this is a critical phase for the future orientation and perceived value of this beta site, so I think it's worth debating...

Body:
Isn't it some kind of backwards reasoning? (If 'we' can prove that we're 'better' than 'them', that proves that we're 'right'?)

You're ascribing too much meaning to those questions. In some cases, it's mere curiosity (my business ethics question) in other cases it can help to make a point (my liberal question) but that point is not "atheists are better." Demographics can be used for so much more than "we are better."

So atheism is churning out a reasonable community on its own merits, but it seems that we should attempt to broaden our scope to prevent things like this | from | happening.

While broadening our scope may not be the best idea (vote as much if you think not), it might help to add content to our site. However, while we might want to make an intellectual landgrab for our favorite context for atheism (in science, epistemology, semantics, etc), those contexts don't benefit our community in and of themselves (I could come up with selfish reasons for epistemology or semantics to be the added domain, but it would be for a reason that wouldn't add value to the site overall, just increase the population of questions). We need to annex a strain of thought that does the whole value-added thing by creating a context to ask questions in, that gives our questions and answers a practical focus.

On meta.stackoverflow I asked about whether other Area51 sites had re-scoped, as it were, before. Here is Robert Cartaino's answer:

Many sites have expanded and contracted their scope after launch. Simply redefining what is meant by "Atheism" is within the purview of that community. There are no technical issues involved; simply coming to a consensus about policy, promotion, and enforcement of the issues with the community.

But, if you are talking about wholesale changes to the definition of a site, I would first raise the issues in meta and build a strong consensus within the community. Chat rooms and schedule chat sessions can be a big help here.

I think a good way of considering how to annex some brainspace is to not think of the annex as modifying our site by simple addition, ie Atheism & Blah. Instead we should have some multiplicative addition; a way of taking our topical knowledge and making it more pointed, more practical, and ultimately more meaningful.

  1. As a first step, vote up this question if you think a scope change is in order. Remember, this is not an idea meant to just add content with & Blah to atheism, but is meant to add context to each and every question asked. It's meant to broaden the scope of what questions about Atheism mean in a practical sense.
  2. Second, let's try to brainstorm some ways to make the Atheism site broader in it's impact, not just its libraries. Try to think of practical edges to add to atheism. Post individual implementations as answers below.
  3. Try to POST 1 ON-TOPIC, & 2 OFF-TOPIC EXAMPLE QUESTIONS a la Area51s process
  4. Third, we can have some scheduled chats, etc (as Robert recommends) as necessary, but we should try to build a consensus for how we would like to add focus to our site. Once we have a plan in place, we can contact the SE community support staff

Again, this is not just to spur questions, but to allow flexibility and encourage a focus in responding as well. Specifically, we don't want to encumber ourselves by adding just some other discipline, but an actual, practical focus. Remember, as it was mentioned, we don't want to add a discipline, and a bunch of its disciples, if all we add is a bunch of people responding to questions that they don't have good answers for, but have loud opinions about. This about adding focus and context, not principally about people and content (they come on their own for the quality).

While it is entirely possible to come up with an occasional poll-style questions that avoids social pitfalls of “Getting To Know You” (GTKY) questions and mindless entertainment, it is pretty rare. It is better just to ask your question with the tools we have now, rather than explicitly encouraging (an even soliciting) "polling"-type questions as a [feature] of this system.

Simply stated, we don't want to encourage polls on this site. The Atheism Stack Exchange is supposed to be about building a canonical archive; a source for authoritative answers to decisive questions.

Polls are typically very basic "what do you think about…" questions that have been asked hundreds of times on every other forum on the internet. Asking interesting and challenging questions is hard. But when you compare that to asking questions out of mere curiosity (one that gives everyone the opportunity to sound off with random opinion), it becomes the low-hanging fruit of the system. More often than not, polls are a quick and dirty way to seed discussion without regard to the quality of the question or the answers.

That is not what we do here. It is the high quality questions and answers (and the high expectations) that separates these systems from the random phpBB noise and junk food found in most discussion forums. So let's not encourage polls, save the few that can get by the strict vetting of the community.

Title: How do we include less conventional forms of non-belief that do not fall under the atheist banner?

Body:
Stating that all statistical studies about the differences between theists and atheists are of dubious value, or silly, or something like that, is wrong. Why? Because that is a sweeping generalisation with no backing.

I can perfectly study the differences between blue-eyed and brown-eyed people regarding their divorce rates, for example, and get some stats. Why not between theist and atheist? Please note that I am not implying anything about the result of the studies here. I am just saying that statistical studies with a correct methodology can be made. Whether or not the outcome shows a statistically significant difference between theists and atheists or not, that's something that I don't know, and will depend on each particular study.

I would criticise a study if it uses a sloppy methodology or inconsistent theoretical underpinnings. But posing a politically incorrect research question is not something that can (or should) be criticised in science.

Similarly, making bold, sweeping statements such as those seen in here is valueless. Each study must be assessed by its own merits, and criticised accordingly, and regardless of its political correctness.

What does the "dubious value" in the question title refer to? Imagine a study that compares a variable between theist and atheist groups of people, using a sound methodology and good theoretical underpinnings. Imagine that this study finds a statistical significant difference between those groups. I don't care about "dubious value" here; there is a fact that I, as a scientist, must face and research further. If, by "dubious value", you are thinking of moral or ethical implications, I don't care about that.
For what it's worth, I would not vote any of these off-topic if you ask about them. The latter two are perfectly within the scope of atheism.

I think most people see atheism as the umbrella covering all non-belief. If you described apatheism or ignosticism to most people, they'd just conclude it's a form of atheism.

Thus, I would say that all forms of non-belief are on-topic.

I just wish to suggest that there be two different tags, one for the case when a question is difficult to answer because of ambiguous semantics and another one for posts that are explicitly about semantics.

Sorry if this seems like a fluffy post, but in order to get better at what we're doing, we should know what we're doing well and what we find valuable as a community.

Body:

Your question is really a corollary to this post: Is this only for atheists?

Certainly, nobody is checking credentials and everyone is free to participate… as long as they stay on topic for this site. If a question veers too much into "Hey! How dare you… how can you justify… Are you stupid?", it is certainly justifiable to close those questions as off topic.

As the saying goes, don't feed the trolls. With that said, it's not because a question is asked by a theist that it's a bad question. Anyone here with over 500 rep is able to edit questions, even questions written by others. This is a great feature, but it entails some risks. Imagine that Alice posts a question and a few people write answers. Later, Bob comes along and edits Alice's question. If Bob's edits are small (i.e. fixing typos, rewording a sentence to make it better), then that's great. But if Bob's edits are so extensive as to significantly alter the meaning of Alice's original question, then the existing answers are probably rendered inadequate. Maybe Bob believes that he is doing everyone a favour by clarifying Alice's words, but how can he know what's in other people's minds regarding the interpretation of the question?

Case in point (see here): recently, I wrote an answer to a question titled:

Is there a genetic basis for belief in a higher power (or, conversely, is there a genetic basis for atheism)?

My answer focused on what I think to be a tenuous link between genetics and religion, as explained by Dawkins in "The God Delusion". After I wrote my answer and left the site, another user (not the original poster), edited the question to something very different:

Has evolutionary psychology explained the origin of religion?

My answer was left there, totally inadequate. To make things worse, the user who edited the question also downvoted my answer, arguing that it didn't address evolutionary psychology, when, in reality, the original question didn't ask for that (but for genetic basis); the "evolutionary psychology" bit was added by this user through his edit after the fact.

A long discussion followed with no satisfactory resolution. In my opinion, this practice of heavy editing where the semantics of a question are significantly altered after some answers exist is not respectful to the community, and not elegant or polite. Therefore, I suggest that we think carefully before we perform lareg edits on a question with answers.

What do you think? How can we make sure that edits (which are a great feature) do not clash with the effort put by other users who have already answered the question? How can we guarantee that we are not twisting the original poster's aim when we heavily edit his/her post?
Title: When is question editing inadequate?

Body:

Body:
"Higher Power" is just a euphemism for God, created by Alcoholics Anonymous. So Stack Exchange is just appropriating that phrase. It doesn't mean anything more. Could it be that this phrase is too idiomatic for a global web site?

Just as a point of clarity - where did you get the bit about "maximal" power? Are you just saying that use of the word "higher" implies that there is also a "highest" (maximal)?

There's another issue in the term "higher power" then a euphemism for God. Scientific thinking sees the world as having a single layer. There is no "behind the scenes" reason for why things happen. For example, consider the question "Why did this car accident happen?". A theist answer might be "because it was so ordained" (by whom?), or "because it was his time to go" - Both implies that there is some invisible arrangement that caused the accident. The scientific answer depends only on the physical evidents: e.g., the driver drove too fast.

The hidden reason behind things if often referred to as a "higher power", i.e., something that causes things to happen in ways that are invisible to us (and therefore, irrefutable). Atheist (scientific, free) thinking does not acknowledge this kind of reason.

I thought that it was a pun. "Skeptics of a higher power" could mean:

  • People who are skeptical that a "higher power" exist
  • More highly powerful skeptics - ie expert skeptics.

I come from a Christian (Mormon) background and, on my own, found my way to atheism. Over the years I've gradually found resources to support my thinking, but primarily in the fields of biology and evolution, my personal interests.

This stackexchange site has provided me with a lot of useful information, arguments, and links to resources that have greatly helped me find answers that better solidify concepts. Just as my programming skill has been bolstered by the stackoverflow site, through Q&A and research, so has my understanding of atheism.

The primary things I have learned about so far from this site are:

  • The excellent works of Richard Dawkins, Christopher Hitchens, and others.
  • Common misconceptions about atheism, agnosticism, and even theism
  • Learned more about the origins and histories of various world religions and the reasons they become so culturally important, stifling (at times) scientific progress.

Compared to other sites with a similar topic, this one is by far the most respectful and contains the least mis-information. So we're doing something right. What some call "trolling", I would call honest questions from people who just haven't considered or researched the questions much. I would much rather a young fundamentalist come here and get respectful responses to their questions than somewhere else and end up in a flame war that will just entrench them further in their beliefs.

If anything, I think we should open it up a bit and quit closing so many questions.

So in light of that example, I think you raise a valid concern. However there are means of addressing it, including commenting on that answer to point out that it's not particularly informative and is disputable. That may lead other people to give other answers more consideration before voting.

On the other hand, that particular question may not engender a more detailed, objective answer than the one given. It's an interesting question, but a rather subjective one. That doesn't necessarily mean that "it's just personal" is correct, but rather that how atheism might inform a particular stance beyond personal opinion is subjective.

This is the difficulty we have with placing the rather subjective topic of atheism in the objective context of SE. Most of the really interesting questions are subjective, and that's ok as long as they're good subjective. I think the question qualifies, but the most popular answer doesn't.

I am becoming more convinced that there are a number of roads to atheism; the rejection of religious belief due to it's incompatibility with an empirical epistemology; the rejection of religious belief on the basis of internal inconsistency, the rejection of religious belief on the basis of the lack of a reasonable justification for such belief.

While each, and in my opinion all, form a sound basis for atheism, it is worth remembering that any position regarding belief is internalised. Religion is an external manifestation of the believer's ideals and neither good nor bad, religion is merely a phenomena to be understood.

The starting point for that understanding is in the analysis of how that belief effects individual actions in relation to others and the world around them. Primarily, it would seem, the key role played by religion is in controlling the believers world view, and by extension the believers view of others. The ability to effect such impact on global affairs is not insignificant.

Given that the atheist has rejected the theist's belief, i.e. there is no defensible truth to the claim, the question then becomes who propagates the lie and why? Clearly there exists a benefit in propagating the lie and that benefit may be measured as power; be it economic (tithe), coercive (warfare, personal or national) or cultural. All of these combine to secure the ongoing relevance of the very beast itself, it is a self reinforcing system.

These things do all of course occur in the secular world as well, however in the secular world they are subject to the scrutiny of the people. Religion, being self referent is not.

The question is who benefits from religion and how?

What I, as a non-believer need, is a place of pluralistic temperament, where I can reason unemotional one day, and make a dry, biting remark the other day, and don't have to apologize for one or the other.

I cannot look into the heads of religious people, and calculate, how my writings might affect their conciousness. I guess some like it dry, some like it hot, some need a subtle tap, and some need a rant. We can't know it - we don't even know who is reading here at all. I guess few. Very few.

Atheism isn't allways a romance with happy end, and, lucky we are, we don't need to sell it. I guess in the long run I will cut a fine figure if I am as I am, and sometimes I'm very fair, serious, and trustworthy, and sometimes I'm just angry and furious - well, and that's ok too. If it doesn't happen too often, and if I don't cross the borders of taste too deeply.

So let's observe us mutually with patience and respect, but without forming an army of uniformed soldiers of scientific misbelief.

And let's have some fun. ;)
