Title: What is the mission of the atheism stack exchange?

Body:
I was really intrigued by this site as soon as I read its title browsing through Area 51. I was quite surprised that it was in beta, because opening such a site seemed almost completely antithetical to the philosophy the StackOverflow people espoused. It seemed absolutely setup for failure, and upon reading the site metrics, and clicking through, I was confirmed. I thought I might offer a couple of thoughts on why this site is an ill-advised idea, at least in my opinion.

First, this site isn't attracting any experts, because of two reasons: The aggressive and gang-like mindset of many of its participants, and because it's impossible to be an "expert" in atheism -- it's a negative position!

The first problem is the most serious, and the least rectifiable. New Atheism, the movement, has changed the tenor of atheists to define themselves oppositionally to theists, their mortal enemy and their persecutors, to whom they must be ever vigilant against. Right now, I have 2 views on one of my questions, with 1 vote to close, and no comment -- most likely because to some in this community my unorthodox views smell like those of a "theist troll." Although it should be pretty clear I'm quite disdainful of atheist activism, I'm not the only one to notice this aggressiveness, and a few voices on meta seem to have already piped up against this increasingly fractious trend.

The second reason is structural, in that atheism, as a negative philosophy or position, cannot have experts. The difference between here, and a productive StackExchange, like Math.SE, where I'm most active, could not be more clear: There, a good user can turn a sow's ear into a silk purse; bad questions can still have remarkable threads because mathematics is explicitly constructive in a extremely well defined way. Here, a bad question just stays a bad question, or worse, becomes flame-bait, because atheism as philosophy is NOT constructive, it's completely agnostic as to moral precepts and values. One might import various moral theories into an atheistic worldview, but then we'd be talking about a Philosophy Stack Exchange, wouldn't we? The discussion level there would be higher, but even there keeping up with constructive questions would require staying abreast of the field in the most esoteric journals, it would be quite difficult...

The best Stack Exchanges, to me, seem to have this quality where responses can be constructive despite bad questions, or limited knowledge: "Hm, A." "I can't answer that, but can answer A/2, which is quite similar..." or "Wow, that is a really bad question B. In fact, B offers a pedagogical exercise in what not to do in related situations C, D & E..." "Really bad B actually occurs as the result of an obscure history...." Etc. They invite specific and targeted questions, and experts to give good answers, because of their explicit constructiveness. Atheism, as a subject matter, lacks that quality.

It would be hard enough that Atheism StackExchange were non-constructive in this way, even without all the belligerency...but with it, there's just little hope.
Title: Is this site attracting experts? Of course not. How can it possibly, given the nature of its subject matter?

Body:
I completely agree with you, and we're not alone. It's been brought up a lot on chat as well.

Though, to be fair, the site has produced good content and if the site was limited to those high quality questions/answers, then the site would make the Internet a better place.

Two examples of those would be:

  • Boy Scouts of America and Atheists: Boycott, or change from within?
  • Was the heated bet in the Hitchens vs. Boteach debate ever conceded by either side?

Both of the above are difficult questions, about atheism and have objective answers.

Unfortunately, that doesn't apply to most questions on this site - and even less so to the most recent questions. When I checked the latest questions earlier today, six out of the last ten were closed or should be closed. Most of the rest were not particularly interesting to answer.

As you point out, there are two problems with the site:

  1. There are no experts.
  2. The scope of the site is too narrow.

About the first one, what needs to be said is that atheism is a topic many people are misled into thinking they are knowledgeable. The unfortunate truth is that philosophy - which is what most questions are about - is a lot harder than they realize. Whole books are written about the philosophy of religion. It's not a topic a layman can claim to master without first doing a lot of reading. Otherwise, he'll inevitably use many arguments that have been demolished decades ago.

As to the second point, it's quite clear that "atheism" is too limited of a subject. There are so many interesting questions that go beyond that scope. that's why it has been suggested to merge with religion or philosophy. Both would be far better suited.

Atheism, alone, is too much of a limited position. It's not metaphysical naturalism or any other coherent belief. Atheism is just one fact about your metaphysical beliefs.

I agree there is belligerence, but what did you expect? I disagree that there are no experts and Robert Price or the guys at Reasonable Doubts are good examples. I think the amount of work that a believer needs to do to throw off a culture that has 4,000 years of history needs to be acknowledged here. There are a lot of people who are completely surrounded by believers and need better answers than "religion is just stupid". You don't need to be an expert in philosophy, but it helps to be a decent amateur in several disciplines, as noted in my answer here.

Also, there are arguments within the atheist community that are very important. The Mithra and Horus myths have come up a couple times, and I chase them down because I think it reflects poorly on my fellow atheists when people use this bad understanding of history to make a point.

The very issue of belligerence is also important. It is not at all unlike the argument between Martin Luther King and Malcolm X, not that atheists as a minority can be compared equally to their struggle, but I assume people are familiar with it so I use it as an analogy. I take the more moderate, conciliatory road and find it very difficult to even get atheists to talk to me about it. I may be wrong, so I appreciate that I have had feedback from people here.

I don't have high hopes for the future of the site, but I'll be sad to see it go. It seems part of the problem is trying to make it fit the stack exchange standard. It seems to me adjustments could be made.

Based on the content of other forums on stackexchange, I had hoped that the questions and answers in the Atheism forum would be similarly polished and professional. Over the past week, or so, it has become increasingly clear that my initial desire will remain unfulfilled.

I do not want to be associated with this forum any more.

Is there any way to drop the Atheism forum from my account while retaining links to the forums with more well reasoned content?
Title: Is there any way to remove my account association to the Atheism forum?

Body:
Here is an initial guide for when to close, and when to edit. The initial knee-jerk of encountering a bad question is likely to be subjective; what appears bad to me may not appear bad to you. However, we need to first qualify what is 'bad' about a given question. I don't think that any one person, or group of people, should or needs to hand down an agenda to be able to assess the questions on this site based on how well they stack up to stack exchange standards.

In terms of who closes questions it is pretty open during this phase of the beta. That is by the SE design. It is important in the sense of any participatory democracy. This site is still carving out a community, the nascent community is still trying to develop a coherent modus operandi. If you think there should be an alternative model, or adjustments made to the closing/editing etiquette, please comment on the thread so that your insight can be applied to the current model.

More tersely, the mission or purpose of this stack is to answer questions about atheism. Questions that do not fit the mold of a stack-exchange-answerable question should be put through the paces of closing/editing; no mission statement needed. However, a thread exists that is trying to find out 'how to ask atheism questions'. From the outset of this stack, we knew the subject was going to be difficult to manage as a Q/A topic and have been trying to create methods for asking questions that steer the question into objective or good subjective territory. If you have any additional comments or suggestions please post.

I'd like to pick up where @Lausten left off:

I don't have high hopes for the future of the site, but I'll be sad to see it go. It seems part of the problem is trying to make it fit the stack exchange standard. It seems to me adjustments could be made.

The problem with this site is its scope. The scope is too narrow. We have banned part (religion) of the topic (atheism), which is integral to discussion, as off-topic. Focusing on the topic is less on task than focusing on the endeavor of the inquiry. There is an unacknowledged subtext to all questions about atheism that does not exist with cooking or superuser'ing.

There is a minimalist/reductionist definition of atheism being used to define the scope for questions, and it is killing the content.

I am not posting to promote my prop on Area 51, however I think that there is an umbrella topic of Comparative Studies (encapsulating Philosophy, Religion, Atheism) that would better allow standards and content for questions to more distinctly emerge. Atheism on its own is too truncated a view of the topic. Semantics aside, I do not believe atheism is a negative position for many people who subscribe to it insofar as it constitutes a building block of their identity. However, to talk about it without discussing what it is defined in contradistinction to (or to assume that any question involving religion is likely off-topic) is far narrower a view than any real inquiry of any topic would allow.

My proposal seeks to unify this realm of inquiry (Philosophy, Religion, Atheism) under one heterogeneous community. In my view, the other two (and most species of religion generally, but not 'Biblical Hermeneutics') will fall into the same gambit where there are 1 or 2 other topics that are integral to the discussion, but off-topic.

For atheism at least, only through the merger of all three of these topics can we set a context for exploring what is both (a) a very scholarly, expert-populated field of study, and (b) a difficult-to-contain-as-"good subjective." What is missing (why this seems un-constructive) is a context, a setting for the Q/As over-arching discussion. By excising Religion from the site and fixating too doggedly on just atheism, perception of the historicity and lineage of this study has languished.

I am always comfortable having my questions criticized. However, there is a default "there is no atheist answer" reply that many people use. For people who believe that the community of atheism is faceless, I feel they are missing an entire component of the inquiry. To not accept that atheism is a choice and creates friction in one's sense of identity is absurd. To close questions because they deal with trying to reconcile theist issues with an atheist perspective seems, on its face, like not facing issues or telling people to shut up.

The problem is less to do with applying atheism to the stack exchange model as it is to not allowing questions to borrow from related topics.

We have a few specific threads open that are trying to grapple with shortcomings of this site. So to complement the "What have you learned?" thread, let's try to find out what aspects we haven't fulfilled.

Please explain below what areas you find lacking in this site. Many people have voiced a desire for a merger or broadening of scope for the site. If we really want to pursue something along these lines, or to seek out any other solution, we really need to hammer down what the major flaws are.

The point of this is to be able to bring together what we are doing right, and adjust the things we are getting wrong (or are at least causing friction). As such, please post:

  • a specific expectation you have for this site
  • how your expectation relates to the topic
  • how this expectation is and isn't being met
  • whether you think this is a community or moderator concern
  • a solution, or an idea of a remedy, or the why of how your expectation is not being met

This is the place to complain. However, please try to avoid being too rantish as it can lead to TL;DR. Also, we are in need of constructive criticism; if you have free-floating gripes without a proposed direction to steer them in it is less likely to help us help ourselves.
Title: The complain thread: What's wrong with this site?

Body:
Okay, I will start.

I have argued elsewhere that atheism is not a good theme for a Q&A site. I won't repeat my complete argument here, but, basically, it goes like this: I don't think it is possible to generate a continuous stream of questions about atheism for which clear answers exist, because atheism is not a field of knowledge. Stack Exchange sites are, by definition, question-and-answer sites, and discourage discussion and debate but for very few exceptions. In my original argumentation, I said that we either relax the requirements that Stack Exchange imposes over this Atheism site, or we should abandon the idea of having it.

Looking at how things are going, I think that this site is not going to fly. Few new questions are being asked and a lot of questions are being closed, with very questionable rigor. This, I believe, confirms my views explained in the previous paragraph.

The only way I can think of to fix this is, as I say, to relax the restrictions imposed by Stack Exchange. I am aware of the reasons why these restrictions exist, and I don't doubt that they are well founded. I am not sure if Atheism would live if we changed the rules, but I am pretty sure Atheism will die if we don't.

It doesn't seem to me that a merger with any individual site would be enough. A merger with Skeptic Exchange/Skepticism or Philosophy would still mean that valid questions about religion are off-topic. A merger with Religion would most likely lead to irritation at best, flamewars and banning at worst. And wouldn't allow some of the questions that a merger with Skepticism/Philosophy would allow.

As mentioned here, part of the problem is that our definition of what is on-topic is too restrictive. So perhaps we would need to merge and expand the scope of the questions we allow?

As someone who has tried to rigourously uphold the Stack Exchange model as I understand it, I have to agree that it's not working. I would much prefer not to close an interesting question just because it's only loosely and indirectly associated with atheism, or because it invites discussion/debate rather than objective (unbiased, concrete, supported) answers.

I'm in favour of relaxing the restrictions imposed by the Stack Exchange mission, as many people seem to have done already, but only to the extent that they don't violate the main goal of enabling experts to provide solid answers to clear questions.

The problematic restrictions are:

  • Questions must be on-topic.

    There are already good places to discuss solutions to this problem. I'm in favour of merging to increase the scope, but also increasing the scope further to allow interesting, relevant questions which are currently (and would still be) off-topic.

  • Questions and answers must be objective (or at least good subjective).

    We're certainly not alone in struggling with this issue. One problem I find is that many questions aren't presented clearly enough, and so lots of responses are generated to tangential topics, either as answers or comments. I think closing such a question is the appropriate course of action, though it should also be made clear to the questioner that their question could be reposted in a more clear and concise form.

    Mfg suggested a course of action which I think would be complimentary; instead of discussing an answer in the comments, ask a separate question. Three potential issues with this solution are, (1) changing people's habits, (2) questions spawned from other questions are quite likely to be seen as too similar, and closed as such, and (3) sometimes a back-and-forth debate is the only option for addressing a particular point of contention. I think the first two issues could be address by having clear guidelines in the FAQ, and active moderators who agree on what those guidelines entail. I don't think the third can be addressed without allowing a discussion/debate.

    So alternatively we could loosen the restriction and allow discussions and debates, while encouraging adherence to the Q&A format. In other words, show a clear preference for the Q&A format (experienced members/moderators could provide guidance), but don't strictly enforce it.

The reason for asking is that from many posts here and on the site proper, as well as closing/reopening behaviour, it's obvious there's a lot of different ideas about what should and shouldn't be allowed. Similar questions have been posed before, however I can't find one which asks for a clear outline of what is considered "on-topic".

It seems we've agreed that Atheism.SE should be merged with another site, though merging with the popular option, Skepticim.SE, would still leave no place for a number of questions related to religion and philosophy which I think deserve an answer (though I'm open to dispute on that point). So while the discussion of merging is taking place, I think it would be helpful to work out a clear scope for the site so that we don't have to go through this entire process again after the merge.

The answer should address which topics are ok, even if they're only loosely related to atheism. For example, what kind of questions about religion are ok? What kind of questions about philosophy, skepticism, humanism, science, community, culture, politics, etc? Though please note I'm not asking for an exhaustive list (though a partial list would be helpful), but rather general principles more obvious than just "about atheism, or related to it". And something the users and moderators can refer to. As a starting point see mfg's answer to what should go in the FAQ.
Title: What should the scope of this site be?

Body:
What do Atheism and Skepticism have in common that Atheism doesn't have in common with [Religion] and Philosophy? Critical thinking.

Atheism is usually arrived at by thinking critically about theism and superstition. Skepticism is, by definition, thinking critically about everything, but woo and magical thinking in particular.

I think the questions you linked to are about [Religion], not atheism, and while they're legitimate questions, they would belong on a Philosophy SE. They're not really about thinking critically. I'd be willing to let the "Is Atheism a theism?" question be answered, if only to point out why the answer is so resoundingly "no."

So the kinds of questions which I would find appropriate for an Atheism and Skepticism SE (or Critical Thinking SE) would be about how critical thinking is applied in practice.

  • Political questions could cover "getting more atheists elected" or "what are non-religious arguments against abortion?"
  • Scientific questions could be "I want to learn about climate change so I can explain it to deniers. Where should I start?" and "Why doesn't homeopathy work? (that is, what's the science behind why it doesn't work)"
  • Cultural questions could be "What secular alternatives are there to the Boy Scouts of America/Alcoholics Anonymous/YMCA?"

I don't think we should define ourselves by what we're against, but rather what we're for. To bring back an earlier comparison, vegans and vegetarians aren't anti-carnivores, they're pro-herbivore. We're not anti-theism (I know some of us are, but that's not the point), we are pro-critical thinking.

Please note that the following subjects are considered off-topic here:

  • Book/Movie/Documentary/Blog swapping
  • General information about religion
  • General information about science
  • General questions pertaining only to philosophy
  • How to humiliate some guy in a coffee shop

Here is the list of items that initially I listed as off-topic. These guidelines are from a while ago and some of them are more open after use.

The reason I listed religion, science, and philosophy as off-topic was to try to have an intellectual boundary; where we could point and say, "we're not the experts on that, they are."

However, I think that in terms of religion and philosophy in particular, an atheistic perspective is valuable and something people would want (if just to share and have evaluated). Also, as those stacks have yet to develop, I think it would not be out of place to exercise and share the philosophical and religious knowledge that atheists do acquire.

In terms of science, if it is about theoretical physics, guess what, there's a stack for that. Point them there. Same thing with biology. If it is about evolutionary psychology, that's a bit of a gray area. Not because there aren't better experts on the subject, but because atheists would be enriched sharing that knowledge.

I am approaching scope from the type of content, rather than the subject of the content. Basically, I propose two qualifications for broadening the scope:

"the content presents..."

  1. Value added: the question is pertinent to a current discussion in atheism, and although it may be tangential to the discussion, the knowledge is generally applicable to atheist knowledge. I.E. The discussion on evolutionary psychology (in the question "Is theism a predisposition?") contributes a theoretical response to the common question asked of atheists, "If there is no God, where does morality come from?"

  2. Heterogeneity in atheism: many of our questions seem to be seeking some definitive answer. However, this kind of expectation of a community as diverse as each individuals deconversion story is unrealistic. We are going to have a stack that is more discussion-y than English Grammar and Usage. That doesn't mean questions cannot demand methodical answers; that doesn't mean answers don't need to show their (critical thinking) work. We should allow a question and answer to dwell more in the 'good subjective' than in the objective; and we should be more strict regarding any dwelling in the 'bad subjective.'

The two concerns I have opening the gate to these two allowances have nothing to do with lowering our standards on the questions/answers (if anything, we need to be twice as rigorous). My concerns are these:

  • Incessant nitpicking: My first concern is that we will feed the bug that insists on creating these mammoth threads in the comments of an answer. I personally find myself distracted by these at the minimum, annoyed and aggravated on bad days. Imagine we had some notable like Hitchens stumble on the site and post an answer, do you think he would stick around if we quibble over every nitpick? Yeah, so cut it out with everyone else. This isn't cooking where bad advice is might end in a case of botulism. You know what works for that kind of discussion? CHAT. Thats what it's for. Go there. (...and if you have some 12 comment thread, and the person makes the edit you needed them to make, then delete your comments.)

  • Inevitability of "Inconsistent Enforcement" QQ: Yeah. We will be inconsistent at first: it will get better and standards will be more formalized. But remember, (a) closing is not permanent, (b) all questions can be re-opened, or asked better. Even the best question or answer can still be better with a collaborative effort. The issue bigger than over-closing, is over-answering. Answering bad questions frequently makes editing questions to be answerable almost impossible. We can occasionally harness the motives of one subjective, vote-to-close-bait question and edit it into an objectively answerable question. Answers on bad questions make editors feel sad. Editors honestly don't want to orphan your answer; also, editors don't want to deal with QQ'ing about how your answer was so great for the original question. If you answered a bad question, and it was edited into shape, you'll want to adjust your answer to fit.

    • I'm less worried about backlash than people being discouraged and not trying to work to forge the framework. It's our shared community. The community determines what flies, so test the boundaries. Try asking the same question a different way if it is closed. If you realize some way of incorporating content that was initially off-topic, share it so that we can codify the what and the why.
    • Nobody is out trying to close questions, or on the prowl. Everyone knows we have a severe lack of content. Closing questions is not a productive solution. Nobody wants to close a reasonable question. BUT Sometimes, when you play the tape to the end, you notice that there are flaws that need corrected about a question. Closing a question is meant to keep people from putting up good answers to bad questions before there is a chance to rectify the flaws. Please try to promptly correct flaws or clarify questions when they are posed of your question.

I'm not up on the technical details of stack exchange, so I'll make a few comments on expectations.

I expected this site to be more aware of the many ways that people are grappling with the issue of atheism in their lives. More members than I expected have some sort of idea of what it means to have crossed a border into atheism from where they can speak clearly about it. I don't think that border is so clear, regardless of any simple definition. People who have come to terms with it personally, frequently have a community, a family or even a spouse who has not. I think the ASE format can supply a format to have those discussions.

A step down from that, are those who are not quite ready to declare themselves atheist. If you aren't aware of the many paths to getting there, take a look at "50 Voices of Disbelief". If atheists are more open and willing to accept someone who is "on the path" toward atheism, I think we will find more people participating in the discussion. Churches have been doing this for decades and it has helped them maintain their coffers. I am suggesting a much less subversive way of this doing this. Churches accept members who are "on the path toward Jesus" and give them plenty of room to not believe in miracles or participate at whatever level they want, hopefully showing up on Sunday and dropping something in the basket of course. This can be anything from a conservative church that focuses on abortion, to a liberal church that sings protest songs from the 60's and rarely mentions Jesus.

In the Q & A, this would mean opening up to someone who says they are not religious for reasons X, Y and Z, but they had a vision once, or a dream, or felt something, or read some website about quantum physics etc. and they want to ask a question about it. Sometimes these types of question may sound more combative. I see these people on the Atheist Community of Austin with Matt Dilahunty, and he almost gets them to see where they are self-justifying or fooling themselves, then he starts laying into them and saying the Bible is completely wrong and ranting about it and he can't see why they can't get it. There are plenty of sites to rant, and I don't need to be linked to "Why is Greta Angry" anymore. If that is what you like, then go to a site that likes that.

If we can reach a happy medium on all of that, then I think we can have better discussion about what is part of human nature and what is imposed on us by an insidious power structure that has reproduced itself across generations. I have the same fear that Nietzsche did, that if we just say "God is dead", without looking at what that means, will it just result in a nihilism? Question like that, mixed with question about god's existence, and what to do for Christmas can make for a rich and interesting site.

edit: Here is an example of something that I can't say I have ever seen on any other atheist site. Nice to see. Hope if continues.

Is anti-theism (opposition to religion) a valid topic for this Stack Exchange?

This question is inspired by Is this just another “religion is bad” site?, but that was also saying bad answers score well.
Title: Is anti-theism a valid topic for this Stack Exchange?

Body:
I think it should be, yes.

To some, anti-theism is closely related to atheism. To some others, it is the same as atheism. And to some others yet, it is opposite, and that very opposition is what makes it relevant, very much like questions about religion (such as this one) are on topic here: because inquiry about one thing is a way to learn about its contrary.

Yes, because anti-theism is an attitude. Some atheists have it (all theism is bad and evil), some don't (live and let live, what harm does it do), some feel that way only about particular aspects of theism (okay in your house but not in my kid's school). I think it's worthy of discussion.

Any support of "yes, this site should include anti-theism" will be the number-one reason this site will fail; no doubt about it.

I've been talking behind the scenes to folks who get this site and are deeply concerned that these questions have become painfully uninteresting. This site was supposed to be about Atheism as a movement and a philosophy, but has fallen prey to a torrent of "let's support our position by talking about how stupid everyone else is." You can call them "debate points" but they are mostly meh.

If you're not seeing the inherent harm in this off-topic ranting, let me draw an analogy: There are many Stack Exchange site who have their own traditional "religious" wars. Apple vs. Microsoft, Linux vs. Windows, digital vs. analog; But in a good Q&A systems, these traditional religious wars do not gain a foothold. Virtually nobody's talking about what stupid thing Steve Jobs did this week, or how Windows has another virus, or — if you want to get more literal — I doubt very much that the up-coming Jewish Life and Learning folks are going to spend very much time debating the divinity of Jesus. It just doesn't happen… except in the Atheism Stack Exchange.

There is a tiny, tiny handful of users who think this site might stand on its own by actually discussing Atheism, in it's own right… instead of worry about what everyone else is doing. But those users — assuming they haven't already moved on — are becoming an inconsequential minority.

I disagree that atheism is a negative position. It is a neutral, non-committal position; a nullative position. This is due to the very nature of belief in things unfounded. Expertise requires knowledge, not belief, and atheism and theism are not knowledge based subjects.

In addition to the areas of knowledge that Lausten mentions, you could argue that atheists should also have some knowledge of Theology in order to counter the so-called Courtier's Reply. You may also want to add (as mentioned on another thread) Geology and Cosmology. However, these scientific areas of knowledge would be used to rebut specific claims about reality that the religious get from their holy books or ideology, which isn't really about atheism/theism.

I disagree with the claims of belligerence and activism; being passive hasn't exactly worked for atheists up to now, has it? And how is this different from the belligerence of the religious exhorting us to convert lest we go to Hell and burn for eternity? Or holding 'God hates fags' signs? Is it just that we're used to seeing this from the religious, and pass it off as just expected religious fervour, but we're not used to seeing it from the non-religious/godless? What's the real difference between 'You're a sinner for not believing.' and 'You're an idiot for believing.'?

I don't see a theist troll, but I do see an accomodationist who says we should be respectful and polite toward those who believe (turn the other cheek?), even in the face of their vitriol. What is it about ancient traditional belief systems that requires this respect, especially when the majority of their claims about reality have been shown to be false?

Also, moral precepts aren't imported into an atheistic worldview (whatever that is). Where do you suppose we imported them from? Morality (by all the manifold names it known) is inherent in a social species in order for populations to survive. I venture that it is religion that has imported morality and twisted it into something else to suit its agenda. You're right in saying that a discussion of morality might take place in a philosophy forum. But then what about Sam Harris's The Moral Landscape? Is there no input from science into questions of morality?

Perhaps instead of simply trashing what it is at the moment, you could offer some constructive thoughts on what it should/could become. I agree that the scope is too narrow. Maybe questions asking "But what about X?" from religious people, or those on the fence, could be answered here allowing posters to display their knowledge re certain areas that cause problems for theists. Maybe more discussion type posts should be allowed.

I feel the best way to expand scope is to allow others (non-atheists, fence sitters, the curious) to come and ask questions about atheism, but also tighten up the policy as to what is not acceptable (preaching, cursing, flaming, obvious trolling). Maybe change the name to AtheismAnswers.SE (a play on words; 'answers' as both a plural noun and a third-person singular verb conjugation)
Oh well. I couldn't agree more with @Konrad Rudolph. I've argued for this elsewhere so I won't repreat it here.

Anti-theism is bound to be a topic of context.

That is, to be properly considered, one needs to address the usage of it. There are bound to be loose interpretations, or connotation based uses. For Anti-theism to be properly on-topic it needs to meet two standards: academic rigor first, social appropriateness second. Content that does not meet the following criteria should be flagged, and questions should be closed as "Argumentative & Subjective".

In terms of Academic rigor, the usage must meet the following criteria:

  • Anti-theism is not personally antagonistic of theists necessarily; as a position it is at most adversarial. Consequently, usage of Anti-theist argumentation directed toward theisTS is off topic and should be flagged. Disguising rancorous or condescending talk as thoughtful or well-researched shows a lack of respect for the community.
  • Anti-theism is not a sentiment, it is not a feeling. Proper usage contains the specific "doctrine antagonistic to theism; 'denial' of the existence of a God; opposition to God"; further, "To be clear, 'opposition to God' is not in most meanings a statement that an anti-theist believes in a deity but opposes the being, but for various reasons the position that it would be bad/immoral for such a being to exist.(wiki)"
  • Anti-theism as a concept is used as an indicator of antipathy for belief in theism. "The concept allows a distinction to be drawn between the simple indifference or apathy towards theism, atheism, or agnosticism (cf. apatheism)... Antitheism has been adopted as a label by those who take the view that theism is dangerous or destructive.(wiki)"
  • Anti-theism, in a literal usage, can be used in a fashion to ask about activism as an atheist (strong atheism is a part of anti-theism, and anti-theism ties into secularism very frequently). When considering whether Anti-theism is being appropriately used in this fashion, ramp up the standards for the question itself:
    1. Did the question-asker make it very clear what the problem is?
    2. Did the question-asker make it very clear how to provide good answers?
    3. Does the question give a tangible context for the question, or are they asking a general question that applies in all manner of situation?

In terms of social appropriateness:

  • Personal attacks are not accepted on any other stack, this is no exception. Honestly, a situation where someone divulges personal information about themselves in good faith makes it even less acceptable.
  • We are trying to engage, recruit and maintain a corps of "experts" on atheism; or at the minimum, thoughtful people who are able to answer a wide variety of questions and have knowledge and sources to back up their answers. Ensure your answer is trying to provide an answer in a novel or well-polished fashion.
  • We are not trying to display our skills at ranting. If you answered the question, and used 4-6 paragraphs without a citation try to go back and break it down. Add a few sources, use a list to condense the salient points. (Hint: the 4-6 paragraphs also leads to TL;DR syndrome)
  • Avoid adding anti-theist flair. Some humor is acceptable, but condescension (especially toward the question-asker) is absolutely unallowable. I don't want to read it before answering, OP's don't want to be chastised, and it makes this a worse place to be. Posts that have extraneous commentary of this ilk should be flagged edited to excise the problem areas (with a comment to inform and explain why). If the answer no longer works, this is a matter for the original respondent to address.
  • (Explanations / Reliance on) Anti-theism will be structural to a very limited set of special cases (i.e. activism related questions). Just as igtheism, apatheism, and specifically strong or weak atheism have limited uses, so does anti-theism.
  • As Anti-theism is specific in that it categorizes a school of thought; it does not make conclusions about a group of people. To assume as much is to cast a net over a very large generalization. Use should not be directed at any particular group of people, only the belief itself.
  • Some questions will arise that are inherently 'Getting-to-know-you' (GTKY), and in the vast majority of cases these should be eliminated. But putting anti-theist behavior on a pedestal doesn't shine to well on said posts survival. Give it a purpose.

It is my opinion that this question needs to be boiled down a bit and some of the rhetorical elements removed. How should this be done?

Please :

  • Use the "original post" thread to suggest edits, or add fully edited suggestions as new answers
  • Use additional answers to bring up key issues that need to be resolved in the question.
  • Include any tagging suggestions.
Title: Editing: Are atheists intellectually honest?

Body:
Original Post

As has been discussed here recently, belief in God is a successful strategy for feeling a bigger sense of importance and purpose in life. God created us as part of a bigger plan; we are all infused with God's spirit; there is an absolute right and wrong; I am going to heaven; etc etc. As someone stated, a person with these beliefs is trading in their intellectual honesty in exchange for comfort and a perceived purpose to their lives.

Atheism is supposedly a break from that self-deception. We value intellectual honesty above a false sense of purpose. But is that really true?

As one example - to many people, one of the most offensive things that a theist can say to an atheist is that you can only be moral if you believe in God. As atheists, we are quick to reject that notion and prove that morality really comes from social norms and religion has merely adopted the same values (mostly), not dictated them. But there's always that implied and unquestioned agreement that we should be moral.

To me, if you want to be intellectually honest all the way down, you have to recognize that there is really and truly no higher purpose to anything, which means there is no such thing as "should". We are here as flukes of evolution, we will live out our lives, and we will be gone. Whether people are kind or unkind to each other has only fleeting and small-scale significance, at best. More realistically, it has no significance whatsoever. In fact, the existence of the entire human race might be over in nothing but a brief moment of evolutionary time.

So it seems that even atheists are still stuck in the pattern of trying to find significance and purpose where there is none. Bleak as it may be, the reality is that there is no purpose. If we choose to pretend that there is so that we can live "productive" lives, we should at least recognize that we're doing it for those reasons. Assuming of course that we really do value intellectual honesty. To me though, it just feels like the Matrix, where a few people are intentionally allowed to "escape" in order to foster the belief that they have beaten the system and thereby keep the system going (ignoring, of course, that the last Neo was a true singularity and really destroyed the Matrix, which I thought ruined the story). We have shed one layer of intellectual dishonesty - that our purpose comes from God - but still cling to a lower layer - that we still have a purpose.

But why does anything matter? Why should someone who understands that there is no higher purpose waste time and energy adhering to social norms, trying to be "good", etc? The normal response to that is - by being a good citizen and friend, you create an environment that is better for yourself. By why does that matter? Why should I be happier with lots of friends and money than I would be as a lonely bum in an alley? Or rather, why should I care that I would be happier. And yes, society would fall apart if everyone thought this way, but you already know my answer - so what?

The honest answer is that it doesn't matter. I would experience some "discomfort" as a bum in an alley, but even that is not a "bad" thing. It's just my brain trying to induce me to avoid a situation that reduces my chances of spreading my genes, because that's what it has evolved to do. But the only reason I try to spread my genes is that I have evolved to try to spread my genes, nothing more. And yet, none of us stop trying to live "better" lives. The social and genetic programming in us is much too strong for that.

Back to the title question - are we really being honest to ourselves? Or does being atheistic help give us a false sense of being "intellectually honest" and allow us to avoid the question just as effectively as theists do? And is this especially true for those of us who were formerly religious and now congratulate ourselves on having broken free?

(And I fully recognize the double hypocrisy inherent in even asking this question, and in doing it anonymously. If I truly believed that it didn't matter, I wouldn't have bothered, right? So yes, I am as guilty as anyone in finding it hard to let go of my own self-importance.)

As has been discussed here recently, belief in God is a successful strategy for feeling a bigger sense of importance and purpose in life. God created us as part of a bigger plan; we are all infused with God's spirit; there is an absolute right and wrong; I am going to heaven; etc etc. As someone stated, a person with these beliefs is trading in their intellectual honesty in exchange for comfort and a perceived purpose to their lives.

Even when saying it is to be more "productive", haven't we still just shed one layer of intellectual dishonesty (that our purpose comes from God) while clinging to another layer (that we still have a purpose)?

  • Is being a good citizen and friend, and creating an environment that is better for yourself inherently valuable to justify spending one's limited time and energy (by adhering to social norms, trying to be "good", etc)?

Aversion to discomfort is a survival mechanism; this aversion generates my reactions of 'good' and 'bad'. It's just my brain trying to induce me to avoid a situation that reduces my ability to spread my genes, because that's what the mind evolved to do. The only reason I try to spread my genes is that I, as an organism, have evolved to try to spread my genes, nothing more.

As a constructive suggestion, I would like to propose 3 topics that be considered relevant to being a self-declared atheist, and hence on-topic for this site.

Personal Meaning and the Origins of Humanity

Simply declaring a non-belief in a higher power doesn't render us immune to the innate human inclination to search for meaning and purpose in life. There are centuries of thought (both secular and religious) that we can draw from in order to decide for ourselves what it is that prompts us to get out of bed each day.

There are also plenty of questions to be asked and answered regarding the scientific alternatives to religious creation stories regarding the origins of humanity, life, Earth and the Universe in general.

Ethics and Morality

Many modern legal systems are based nominally on particular religious traditions. However, most aspects of the human sense of right and wrong transcend particular belief systems and recur again and again throughout the world. Starting from basic principles of freedom, compassion, honesty and justice, there are many helpful answers to be drawn from philosophy, economics and other disciplines regarding how humans relate to each other and the world.

Secularism, Tolerance and Pluralism

As a particularly significant subset of ethics and morality in the modern world, the separation of Church and State is a powerful force for justice, as it requires that legal systems and government institutions be founded in basic ethical principles rather than arbitrary dictates of a controlling priesthood. However, tolerating differences in personal belief, while enforcing respect for the freedoms for others can require a delicate balancing act, both for the State and for individuals. Dealing graciously with a variety of belief systems, without allowing those belief systems to exert undue influence over science or the legal system is a challenging but necessary activity.

Good Questions

Asking for suggestions regarding organisations, books, websites or other publications that can help with understanding any or all of the above topics is always a reasonable question.

With so many questions related to these topics being highly personal and otherwise arguable based on starting assumptions, Atheism.SE is slightly more tolerant than most SE sites to subjective questions with no right answer. Be respectful, stay on topic and this should be fine.

Bad Questions

If your question includes thinly veiled (or even blatant) assumptions that all beliefs in a higher power are inherently stupid (as opposed to factually incorrect, but perfectly understandable in a social context) then it's a bad question. A meme as pervasive as belief in a higher power doesn't get that way without at least a few points in its favour (even if "in accordance with observable reality" isn't one of them).

If your question is just an excuse to rant, it's a bad question. If you want to rant at the world, get a blog, don't do it here.

On the one hand we hope to live up to the model that:

The Stack Exchange sites neither encourage nor support these "discussions" that cause other types of sites to fail in very predictable patterns. The other question that you mention, which has not been closed, may contain an answer that is offensive to some, but is a question that admits serious reasoning, and even the (to some) offensive answer has a lot of "meat" in it. To me, these two questions constitute a good example of the two extremes of what is bad debate (i.e. plain silly) and good debate (i.e. should be allowed and encouraged on this site).

In summary, and to answer your question: I don't think there is a double standard in the case you mention. I think there are questions of very different kinds.

"Least and most acceptable religions" is a poll question: What sucks the most?

"Placing a range of judgment values upon religion" (to quote your comment to CesarGon's answer) is not "A question about atheism." We're atheists. We reject all religion, pretty much by definition. I've made this analogy before: it's like asking a vegan "which form of meat is the least cruelly obtained?" Sure, you can talk about non-sentient clams vs. torturing calves for veal, but to a vegan, they're both animals who don't deserve to die for our nourishment. On VeganSE, that question would be closed.

"What can science learn from religion? What can religion learn from science?" at least can be answered, even if the answers are subjective and/or offensive. There's room for an actual response, the merits of which can then be debated.

The question was citing a specific example of, what appears to me to be, a parting of the ways in the community. I asked for clarification on how the community at large deals with that.

This question was closed for a few reasons:

  • It was poorly worded
  • It had too many sub-issues to address neatly
  • (Most Importantly) It was about skepticism

They had set up an arbitrary restriction that said there would be no discussion about skepticism itself. For that reason it was closed. I don't believe that anyone particularly argued the case; but it's in their FAQ, their site is flourishing, [gawd] bless them.

I argued against that case. While he called it "philosophical", I consider analysis and critique to be, dare I say methodical and skeptical. At any rate, there is a middle ground to be held. There are questions which are too general, and general questions which apply to analyzing or critiquing method.

An inherent difficulty with creating a general proximity agreement over this middle ground is that in order to evaluate method, all persons must agree to the ends of said method. For skepticism, they might say they agree on the end being reaching the most neutral, objective truth on the matter at hand. With atheism however, the end is not so well defined; individually, much less collectively. To say there is a particular purpose to atheism is like saying there is a purpose to not collecting stamps. Maybe its to free up time for collecting marbles, but that's not really a motivation.

  • The closest thing to a "method" or "purpose" is that of proving that [gawds] do not exist.

It is my opinion (I'll leave it as opinion) that this question is too general. It does not cut into any atheist model, that is, it does not seek to disprove the existence of some [gawd] or to undermine theist argumentation to the contrary. Insofar as claiming [religion has x impact], as we are neither comparative religion experts nor history experts, we are either unqualified to answer the question or the answer is off-topic anyway. Insofar as we ask what methods we use to analyze their impact, even on the most specific example, we are engaging in sharing interpretation.

~~~ I think your question is about method. It is about how to perceive the impact, how to connect the ley lines from historical events to the religions' actions of the time. This is a question about history and religion, and although a question of consequence to atheists, it is not currently a question about atheism in particular or its methods. For me, to be critically and constructively about atheism and its methods, it must do the following:

  • It needs to focus on a specific event (possible time period), and how to draw consequences from it
  • These consequences should support an anti-theist perspective adversarial to a theist position that would otherwise expunge or ignore the impact of a religion on the event.
  • i.e. "What role did the Catholic Church have in the Holocaust? Was it complicit in mass genocide?" (Note: This question allows for both sides to answer and give objective responses. It is incredibly argumentative and objectionable, and possibly not permissable, but if good answers can follow from more refined versions, it might actually draw more people)*

This is why the "Was Hitler a Catholic?" question (or however that was posed) was on-topic. Churches seek to affiliate themselves with their best, and disassociate themselves with their worst. Setting a specific purpose to the question would turn it around; it would give meaning for anyone interested. It could be filed under debate-points or we could come up with a new one like churches-gone-wild.

Actually, this might light up the switchboards on new questions.

Now, does this answer the question currently posed? No. However, I don't think the question is answerable. Follow-up: Should it be community wiki? Maybe, and that would change some things. If we repurpose the question, it can serve as a living repository for how different atheists think through these matters. (BTW: I am not one to actively suggest we should create a CW, I generally hold out hope the question can be refined. This might be the best exemption of that rule ever though.)

I am having a difficulty composing a suitable, spelled out, example question that doesn't sound heinous. My fear with a churches-gone-wild question, is that if we end up with a massive amount of them, they will devolve into horrible, horrible scapegoatings, stone-thorowings. The only way of putting that in check is to use examples where there is some explicit denial on the part of a possibly culpable religion. Perhaps abortion clinic bombings? I don't know, obviously this is not good or prime for front page yet, but refinements can be made. Obviously this isn't all about traffic or feeding each others' egos (I, for one, do not want to participate in hateful games); but debunking denialism of the darker corners of the churches seems like a fair motive.

tl-dr
To create a "genre" of question here, I propose that we start a churches-gone-wild section. What is it exactly? What should we put in there?

This wasn't a matter of a site that needed a bit more time to reach critical mass. Many sites have flat, horizontal traffic for a long time before they take off — that is completely normal. But the Atheism site was in a long-running, steady decline. Read this; There is further discussion of the situation here: Is the site likely to get out of beta?

But even beyond issues of "traffic" and the size of the subject and audience, most of the core users have lost interest and left the site. Most of the users I talked to find that the content had become uninspired and "painfully uninteresting." The questions on the front page have drifted further from any canonical treatment about the subject of Atheism.

In short, I think the subject had run its course and simply had nowhere else to go.

I think, frankly, that the S.E model of "factual right answers" isn't really all that well suited to debate-centric topics like this one. I also agree that the topic was pretty narrow.

Also, I think the inherited user base of know-it all computer geek types was pretty off-putting to people who weren't part of that group. Without meaningful influx of new blood, the whole thing turned into masturbation in short order.
